1110827800599162881.text:
I tend to refrain from opining on every topic that gets raced around this cursed medium, but then I got reminded that I have good expertise & a unique perspective on speaking at conferences (and other events).

So here goes: The Nuanced Thread about Public Speaking, Tech Edition:

1110876979438501889.text:
Here is how “random folks demand shit from you on the Internet goes”

- posts on medium: why do you post this on medium, host your own blog

- hosts own blog: why don’t you have feature XYZ, all the platforms have it…

You can’t win.

If you don’t have anything nice to say stfuhttps://twitter.com/montogeek/status/1110873531712192512 …

1110837251938893830.text:
I'm extremely grateful I got to make this experience early on in my speaking career 

Tune in next time, when I'll tell you about my absolute worst speaking experience ever.

1110837250563149825.text: After that experience I was confident I could hold my own in any ever so hostile crowd (this one wasn't), because my escape hatch for anything I don't know was saying "I don't know". Trying to cover this up any other way makes the audience lose confidence in you.

1110837249225252865.text: At the meet & greet after my talk, it turns out the person asking the very though question is the inventor of the brainfuck programming language, one of the most hardcore things to bend your head around in programming.

1110837247908155393.text: The. one person asks a very tough™ question. *gulp* and instinctively I say, "I don't know, I'd have to look that up". Crisis averted, not knowing I stumbled into the only way to handle this situation properly.

1110837246549213186.text:
I'm giving my first CouchDB talk in English, which is my second CouchDB talk ever and milt third talk overall. I'm a raw rookie.

The talk goes well and I get a few questions as interruptions that I can answer off the cuff.

1110834388034600960.text:
I’m waiting for the bus, so why not deliver the other thread right away.

One of the skills you learn as a speaker is dealing with audience interruption. For smaller settings (<30) I usually suggest folks interrupt me any time they have a question.

So here I am in Zurich…https://twitter.com/janl/status/1110827826452803584 …

1110827838649839616.text:
Whatever it is, you can try to get more out of a speaking engagement that is just the talk on stage (oh, recorded videos are great for your CV), but you have to see for yourself if the equation resolves in your favour or not. If not: walk away. 

FIN/AMA

1110827837622272000.text: …or you get to do some consulting on the side and you can piggy-back on the transport cost covered, or milk the speakers dinner for all its worth and try to open doors for yourself. Or get in deep with one of the sponsors that you think should hire you.

1110827835835498496.text:
and either is fine.

Just don’t get lulled into doing overtime because a big wig conferences tries to guilt you into doing your talk for exposure and career advancement alone. Find out how else they can benefit you. Maybe the fly you to a. nice place and you get some time off,…

1110827834162012160.text: …you continue to evolve your skills in terms of concentrating a topic into 30 minutes, learning about effective presentation skills, including animation and graphics (or just 600pt emoji, ), people skills, holding attention of a crowd, dealing with (sometimes hard) feedback…

1110827832459120642.text: But that’s just it, giving a talk a local user group is less effort, less risk and less stressful than going up on a professional event, so try that first, and if it stinks, that’s okay, you learned it is is not for you. Or that lights a fire under you to be better at this and …

1110827829959294976.text: On the flip-side, I have seen folks go from a local user group (@berlinjs) to our @jsconfeu and then straight to the big league like WWDC or Google I/O, because incrementally we were able to support a person that was totally deserving of having a large platform.

1110827828906479616.text: …doesn’t display the right amount of charisma, you can certainly work on it, but there are folks for which that comes more naturally, and this racket favours them and makes more work for you to be good at (which you can decide to do or not to of course)

1110827827786670080.text: But all of this doesn’t mean that if you just put in all time, you’ll have a guaranteed career boost. Maybe your topic isn’t widely applicable and it is going to be hard to find a real audience for it. Speaking is performance, if your stage persona (cf. https://writing.jan.io/2013/05/10/how-to-give-the-killer-tech-talk-a-pamphlet.html …)…

1110827826452803584.text: Those skills btw, are generally useful to have, so this isn’t something that’s just expenditure on your end. Being able to present your ideas concisely while keeping an audience’s attention is going to help you in every meeting (hello Hecklers, but that’s another thread).

1110827824775086080.text: Whether you are going to be successful as a speaker depends early on your person, the topics you choose to talk about and the time you are willing to spend on improving your skills speaking.

1110827823005089792.text: I’m still friends with people who I met nearly 20 years ago, working on PHP 4 at the time. That same friends incidentally helped kickstart my speaking career 10 years ago, and today we do extremely different things, but remain friends (Slight tangent end).

1110827821318979584.text: Having gone through this myself a few times I could assure them: the tech comes and goes, the people and relationships stay (modulo the crass racist and sexist culture in tech that makes too many people quit).

1110827819490312192.text: A while ago a friend discussed the option of leaving their high profile position at an open source project I also worked on and he was worried that our relationship would suffer.

1110827818361995265.text: I still have connections like this from 10+ years ago. If there is one universal truth in tech communities it is that you always meet at least twice and you will never know what the second set of circumstances are going to be, so make sure the first one is good. Slight tangent:

1110827815522439168.text: If you get to do more than one talk (or the same talk at multiple events), and especially when these are smaller and more regional events, people will love you forever just for the fact that you took the time to travel to be with that community.

1110827814444560384.text: Having a more diverse view of the world intrinsically makes you do better work. Doing talks is one of the cheapest and most efficient ways to get at that, short of working in DevRel, where you do this for a living.

1110827813379211264.text: …your next job, or you learn about a perspective on your topic, or about an adjacent topic you hadn’t encountered yet. For sure you will learn about the local community and its values and takes on how to do tech and life and that experience alone is incredibly valuable.

1110827811978297344.text:
This turns the tables completely from just attending a conference and getting the most out of it (h/t @polotek https://twitter.com/polotek/status/1044353337930313729 …): people have a reason to approach you.

Things you get out of meeting people are varied, maybe you make that crucial connection that lands you…

1110827810686410752.text: …career needle very far. But you likely don’t *only* give a talk. You also get to go to an event where you can meet other people, including the organisers, other speakers and of course all the attendees, who have a reason to approach you about your talk.

1110827809231028226.text: Preparing and giving talks, especially good talks is a lot of work, no argument there. And some events tout speaking at them as a privilege you have to aspire to, to be worthy to do so. And as a flat calculation, giving one talk at that one conference is unlikely to move your…

1110827807553265664.text: I’m also the co-founder of @berlinjs, which has brought 100s of new voices into our community that wouldn’t otherwise been given a chance to try this out at other events. Since I left active organisation of the group, it has become even more supportive of first time speakers.

1110827805783322624.text: I’m also one of the organiser of @jsconfeu which has had 500+ people speak over the last 10 years, and I helped start @berlinbuzzwords with similar metrics. A narrative of “speaking is bad actually” naturally goes against something I obviously feel strongly about.

1110827804114018306.text: You probably won’t give that many talks and I don’t recommend aspiring it personally or professionally. Speaking might even be not at all for you, and that’s totally fine. A community that only exists of just-speaker-types is extremely boring and by design non-diverse.

1110827802067124224.text: To get my credentials out of the gate, and I’m not even trying to humbly brag about this, because it was a lot of work on my part and a lot of good will and generosity on the part of the 300+ events where I have given talks, but that’s a lot of talks.

1011971485601329152.text: 16. If any of the above is in any way relevant to you, and if you think we could be of service, please get in touch, either reply here, DM me, or email us at hi@neighbourhood.ie or read more about us at https://neighbourhood.ie  — We’d love to work with you! <3

1011971484070432769.text: 15. tl;dr: we care deeply: about our work, the people who work for us, and our clients. We care about The Web and we care about Open Source. We also care about the communities we are part of, and the social footprint we leave behind.

1011971481998450689.text: 14. We’ve done project work in all of the above areas: @CouchDB/@PouchDB/@hoodiehq, Offline First, mobile & full-stack web app development, rapid prototyping, dev team building, crisis-response tech, dev-tooling, for all kind of clients, from non-profits to the Fortune 500.

1011971480744325120.text: 13. We help companies grow their technology architecture along with their teams. With extensive knowledge in scaling databases, backends and streamlining frontends and organising teams to go along with that change, we can help support your growth.

1011971479259492352.text: 12. If you are using GitHub in any meaningful form, we are almost guaranteed to be able to help you save money and time and streamline processes by automating away chores. This helps avoid repetitive tasks and errors, and makes your employees happier.

1011971477900529664.text: 11. We’re experts in writing companion apps for GitHub workflows that integrate both with development workflows as well as non-tech contributors that have an impact on development (say, Legal in larger Enterprises, e.g.).

1011971475908255745.text: 10. We pioneered the JavaScript dependency update automation genre with @greenkeeperio three years ago, which we just released version 3 of: https://blog.greenkeeper.io/announcing-greenkeeper-3-1504f5113998 … — automating tedious chores and keeping your software up-to-date and secure.

1011971474398183424.text: 9. We started and help organize @jsconfeu, one of the most prestigious and biggest JavaScript events in Europe, with sister-events around the globe. We helped set a standard for inclusion and diversity in professional tech conferences.

1011971472968110083.text: 8. We started http://offlinefirst.org  and helped start the @OfflineCamp series of events to bring designers and developers together to form a community that cares about providing applications that work no matter what.

1011971471525253120.text: 7. We’re providing first-class production support for anyone running @CouchDB. We have clients among the Fortune 500 as well as early-stage startups and other SMBs. As part of our work, we heavily contribute back to the open source project Apache CouchDB.

1011971470069846016.text: 6. We started @hoodiehq as an Open Source framework that helped us build apps that continue to work in challenging network environments with ease, at a time when Progressive Web Apps were still a glimmer in the eyes of browser implementers.

1011971468580843521.text: 5. We helped launch a mobile companion app for people with type 2 diabetes for regions with insufficient medical systems, and social stigmata around the illness. Coincidentally, like the Ebola work, this was designed to work in usually-offline mobile network scenarios.

1011971467091771395.text: 4. Some things we’ve done in the past: bootstrapped & recruited a 30 person development team for a non-profit that helped with the 2013-16 Ebola crisis. We helped build tools that helped stem the crisis, and to run the clinical study that lead to the first ever(!) Ebola vaccine.

1011971465397272577.text: 3. Our friend @paulca of @useTito said it best: our books don’t make VCs giddy, but our accountants happy. We’re not here for the latest hype & hypergrowth, we’re not here for the long hours, we’re here to build great products and provide meaningful service to our customers.

1011971463665070081.text: 2. We’re proudly & unapologetically a company that considers itself to be part of the German Mittelstand https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mittelstand …. We are not a startup, we’re not a family, we founded this company to provide meaningful work for our employees by building meaningful products.

1108300144511016960.text: And to our surprise, within minutes of opening in 2017, the Community Lounge became the most favourite part of the conference for many of our attendees. There isn’t a minute when the space isn’t buzzing. This year, the Community Lounge runs its own Call for Stories & Artists:

1108300143328153600.text: in 2017, @jsconfeu added our Community Lounge, our in-event space for showcasing Berlin initiatives, open source projects and meetups right at the heart of our conference. All this largely spearheaded and flawlessly organised and executed by @sheley.

1108300142275452929.text: I can state without hyperbole (for real this time) that we helped put Berlin on the map for wide international technology audience. And the number of open source projects, companies, friendships and even families that came out of these connections are too many to count.

1108300141226835968.text: Since 2009, we made our social events open for everyone in Berlin, not just for conference ticket holders, to make sure everybody who makes the trip out to our lovely city has a chance to get the most out of it and make as many connections as possible.

1108300140203380736.text: Speaking of things I’m proud of. At @jsconfeu we’ve always seen our attendees and speakers coming to Berlin as a big chance to both show off what happens in the local community, and bring together those in the local communities with like-minded enthusiasts from around the world.

1106129121833353216.text: Yet another proof that I can turn any anecdote about curiousities in computing into cautionary tales that should make everyone drop Last-Write-Wins conflict resolution like a hot potato.https://twitter.com/janl/status/1106117837859573760 …

1106128851221037057.text:
…Last-Write-Wins systems will casually and randomly make the wrong choice based on time, and that directly translates to randomly using customer data.

And all big name APIs that you love using are built on this principle. Be sure you know what you sign up for.

1106128720920829952.text:
So if you want to lock someone out, a time-based conflict handling is good, because you can default to be secure.

But…

1106128068261957633.text:
…on the circumstances and usually cannot be guaranteed to mean “casually latest”.

(Except for Google Spanner, but if you have the resources to build that, I’m not sure why you’re taking programming advice from me).

1106127487711490048.text: In other situations, you may use time to make other sorts of decisions. For data systems, this often includes the notion of last-write-wins (or LWW), which sounds intuitive on the face of it. But as we have seen in the fallacies of time, “last” heavily depends …

1106127014900174850.text: …client & server have to agree on the same time to begin with. The built-in data conflict is deliberate and good, because now the default behaviour is that you don’t get a valid token, which is great from a security standpoint (cf. “the failure mode of a train”, it stops safely)

1106126331023159297.text: In more general terms, what we encountered was a data conflict. One that was specifically built into the authentication mechanism used by GitHub Enterprise: in order to avoid getting access for longer periods of time, access tokens are time limited. But to get a valid token…

1106125600727711744.text:
…we’re getting close now. We create an issue and immediately see the problem: “created two minutes ago”, but it was just a few seconds in “reality”.

That had to be it! In lieu of better alternatives, we turn the time for the machine that runs Greenkeeper back two minutes…

1106125069892415489.text: So just for fun, we check the time on the machine that runs Greenkeeper and that looks good. But we don’t have access to the machine that runs GitHub Enterprise, so I suggest a quick trick: create an issue somewhere and look at the relative timestamp that GitHub shows there…
